parent.body:
Not at all. Jesus told his followers to keep nothing but a sword, not even the clothes on their back.

But you don't believe that's the best way to act, because of course you don't, it's ridiculous, and because that's never what the Church has been about. But that is was what Christ's personal discipleship was about. There's an inarguable separation there. I'd hardly say it was a Jewish institution or anything like that, Jesus spent something like 3/4 of his ministry telling the Jews (mostly Pharisees) that they're all going to Hell!

Re: Church Fathers and Revisionism. I'm not an infalliblist (is that a word?) but just for practical purposes, you kinda have to take the New Testament as a body of work or not, because it's literally impossible to know what's legitimate and what isn't. Homologoumena and Antilegomena certainly don't hold up as categories anymore. The Critical Scholars take their guesses, but they also have a habit of smelling smoke where no fire exists. Instead, it's best to take it as "good enough to get a pretty reasonable idea of what the ideal Christian archetype is."

That's also what the early Church Fathers were, and I don't think you can throw them out either. Not because of some wishful notion of consensus like the Roman Catholics have. They aren't perfect, but they're also a lot more connected to the society from which Christianity emerged than we can ever hope to be, they likely had knowledge and sources that we don't even know exist. A lot gets lost in transmission over two thousand years, even when it's written down, because the language fundamentally changes. The Fathers are our lighthouses.

parent.body:
I do wish that families could be more amiably under one roof, even with extended family, but I understand the complications causing households to be mostly nuclear only. Having extended family under one roof, or even just nearby in separate homes, makes a great deal of sense. Unfortunately it's usually functionally problematic. 

That said, I don't think either living nuclear family only nor extended multi family home are necessarily good or bad, inherently. It's more about how you live your life than where you live.

body:
Mark and Luke are much more likely to be authentic, and Mark is also the oldest, not Matthew. I do believe Matthew probably wrote a gospel first, as there's no other reason to attribute something like that to him, however, that is definitely *not* the Matthew we have in our Bible today, which copies from Mark as does Luke. From what I've gathered the original Matthew was a short narrative written in Hebrew, consisting of a few major events but mostly just teachings and parables, just as described in the earliest times. This was translated into Greek and incorporated into Mark's and Luke's gospels as well as the current Matthew. Since our Matthew likes to expand and mix and reorganize things like many ancient writers, Luke is actually a lot closer to the original Matthew because he mostly opts for a more factual retelling without changing much aside from poorly written language. 

The reason Matthew is usually preferred is for exactly the reason I described, because people like flowery and memorable literature, and whoever wrote it had an amazing talent for that.

parent.body:
Matthew is the Gospel people tend to take as the "canonical" account of events. That is to say, they're all canonical, but when people are reciting a synoptic event, if it's in Matthew, that's usually the version you're going to get, and there's a reason for that.

It's the most likely to be correct based on authorship traditions. Mark is a rough 2nd hand account from Peter's sermons, and Luke/Acts was written by a companion of Paul who most likely wasn't actually there for Christ's ministry.

body:
We know Jeremiah 8:8 is speaking of the scribes who copy the scriptures because it says they don't have the law of God? Why not? Because the scribes have been dishonest with it. And not just any law, but it specifically uses the word *Torah*. And less than one chapter earlier leading up to this statement God insists that he never asked for animal sacrifices (Warning: this is blatantly changed in most English editions). Well turn to any one of the first five books of the Bible and in that book alone "God" is found demanding various animal sacrifices reminiscent of pagan practices (especially the "savory aroma" part). Sometimes as atonement for the pettiest of offenses, very often for things that aren't even the fault of the person, and also to gain his favor just like a pagan god. And we know the people in the Old Testament struggled immensely with paganism and idolatry, and we find God complaining about "meaningless sacrifices" multiple times throughout the prophets. From this evidence alone we can confirm Jeremiah 8:8.

In other places God and his followers often break the laws of the Torah. In some of the older stories it's clear that no one knew some of them existed. Much of Jesus's ministry involved being judged for breaking fake laws that the Jewish religion made up.

Your proof-texts are easily explained. Ezra is almost certainly the main scribe who redacted the Old Testament into its modern form, so of course he's going to put a lot of emphasis on the book, because he himself wrote half of it. One of his main complaints was that people were polluting the "holy race" with goyim and Samaritan races, which doesn't exactly help his case. Jesus himself was of the Samaritan race, being descended from the Davidic lineage.

Daniel merely references something from the law given by Moses. That's all he does. He does not contradict Jeremiah, unless there's nothing authentic left in the law according to Moses.

Matthew 5 has the only quote from Jesus that might actually be disputing Jeremiah. However given that it literally contradicts the very sermon it's part of on nearly every point, let alone all the other times Jesus denounces the supposed law, and isn't attested anywhere else except a one-liner in Luke that seems edited in and is in an entirely different spot...this is probably another example of a forgery.

In Matthew 12 Jesus actually agrees with me. Jesus explicitly gives the Pharisees an example of a law that David did right by violating, according to their own scriptures. Thus this law is either a forgery, not all-binding, or misinterpreted. Either way, sola scriptura falls apart.

Mark 10:19 I think you got the verse number wrong.

Another common proof-text which you did not list but is very common is when God's word is described as "pure" or something similar. But when actually read in context it becomes clear that it's speaking of God's faithfulness to his word (trustworthiness), not the accuracy of written scriptures copied over several millenia.

In the context of the conversation, "We worship the Bible" simply meant we follow the Word of God rather than the Church's commands. 

As for Jeremiah 8:8, we know "scribes" can simply refer to teachers. It wouldn't be accurate to assume it speaks on an altered version of the law rather than the commonly described false teacher. It also wouldn't be accurate to assume that God, after threatening complete destruction over his word's apparent editing, turned a blind eye for the rest of time, during which multiple prophets (Nehemiah 8:13-14,18, Daniel 9:11-13) don't seem to show any doubt on the Word. In fact, Jesus (Matthew 5:17; 12:5; Mark 10:19) seems to be out of the loop as well.

As to all your other claims, not that I disagree with them, but I'd like the sources. It gets tiring real fast to speak on an empty box.

body:
It's hard to say if there was a literal global flood. There is some evidence for it but there is also some to the contrary. And we know that mythology was extremely popular in ancient times, with some stories being completely made up and others exaggerated to ridiculous ends. In those times, the meaning was what mattered, not the history. It could've been completely made up, or been an actual bad flood but not anything unnatural, or it may have actually happened. And in that case "the whole world" could mean anything from the world that Noah knew of to the entire actual globe.

But it doesn't matter because all races had to have come from the first human no matter who it was.

post.body:
Noah and company also descended from Adam and Eve.

So the races must have "evolved" from Noah's time until today, didn't they?

A literal reading of the story of the Flood was that the whole world was destroyed except for Noah and a few others, so then the different races that we see today must have genetically come from this lineage.

Does anyone have any more understanding or info on this topic?

UPDATE: [Deluge Catholic Encyclopedia article](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04702a.htm) admits some other possibilities, for example: 

> Besides, the oldest Egyptian monuments present the Negro race just as we find it today, so that even at that remote age, it was wholly different from the Caucasian race.

> Considerations like these have induced several Catholic writers to regard as quite tenable the opinion that the Deluge did not destroy all men outside the ark.

This just moves the question back to how the races descended from Adam and Eve though

body: You claimed Matthew is the most reliable gospel and a firsthand account and should take precedence over Mark and Luke. I disputed your claim because Mark came first and Luke follows older sources more closely, and Matthew was almost certainly not written by Matthew. I don't write off everything he says but I keep in mind that he paraphrases a lot and likes to add in metaphors and literary devices, and that can change the meaning. Compare the Sermon on the Mount with the Sermon on the Plain, or the two Lord's Prayers and you'll see what I mean.

body:
John is definitely edited. Luke also underwent an anti-Marcion revision. Matthew had the virgin birth added at some point, other than that it's hard to tell. Mark is mostly left alone.

The gospels were not attributed until halfway through the second century. In fact they aren't used at all until Justin Martyr. The church fathers before that did mention things written down by Matthew and Mark, which is probably why their names are used; however Matthew at least does not fit the description of our Matthew, which even mentions Matthew in 3rd person. The Matthew they speak of was a collection of logia (sayings) which they specifically say were written in Hebrew. Our Matthew is a lot more than just some logia and is definitely not a translation from Hebrew. If he wrote it he waited quite a while to do so, and he relied quite a bit on second hand accounts even though Matthew should be a primary source.

> I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

There's nothing wrong with using a translation.
body_html:
John is definitely edited. Luke also underwent an anti-Marcion revision. Matthew had the virgin birth added at some point, other than that it's hard to tell. Mark is mostly left alone.

The gospels were not attributed until halfway through the second century. In fact they aren't used at all until Justin Martyr. The church fathers before that did mention things written down by Matthew and Mark, which is probably why their names are used; however Matthew at least does not fit the description of our Matthew, which even mentions Matthew in 3rd person. The Matthew they speak of was a collection of logia (sayings) which they specifically say were written in Hebrew. Our Matthew is a lot more than just some logia and is definitely not a translation from Hebrew. If he wrote it he waited quite a while to do so, and he relied quite a bit on second hand accounts even though Matthew should be a primary source.

I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

There's nothing wrong with using a translation.

parent.body:
You misunderstood my claim. I said that his is the most commonly referenced, and then you went about discrediting it. But, you can't really, I could just as well call into question any of the 4 Gospels. We can't prove that they haven't been revised and altered (although if any one of them has, it's John, and we actually do have some compelling manuscript evidence for that.)

Why couldn't Matthew have been written by Matthew? I can't imagine it was attributed to him for no reason. Even if he referenced Mark or the Q document, it's actually not such an odd thing to do, if you want to make sure you aren't misremembering. Same can be said for Luke, memory is frequently fallible after all. I'm sure the critical scholars will come up with a reason to doubt, but as helpful as they are, they tend to exaggerate skepticism when it's uncalled for. I've seen it claimed that entire epistles should be removed because they quote the Septuagint instead of the Hebrew.

body: Marcion's gospel seems edited too (he removed the baptism and the genealogy and anything supporting Judaism) but it's also got plenty of differences and missing content that Marcionites didn't have a reason to object to as far as we can tell, and in those cases they show signs of being later additions to canonical Luke. It also has things that contradict Marcion's theology which doesn't make sense if he merely went through Luke and took out everything he objected to. And something like 90% of the material missing from Marcion's gospel is unique to Luke. We also know that Luke has been revised in the past due to the quite obvious addition of the first two chapters.

parent.body:
Halfway through the 2nd century is not that late. They didn't attribute works the same way we do today, it was most likely assumed authorship. Is it possible it's wrong? Yeah, but that shouldn't necessarily be the default assumption.

On the issue of 3rd person reference: People usually didn't write narratives from the first person perspective in the ancient Near-East, and in fact, if they did, you would immediately pin it as a fraud, it's one of the most distracting elements of the Book of Mormon, for example.

The Gospel of John was most likely written by a man named "John-Lazarus" a principle character in the story of that Gospel, who was raised from the dead. We only know his proper name was John because Clement refers to him that way in his writings, and it's simply been misattributed to the Apostle John for most of Christian history because it's such a common name (there are similar issues with "Mary") But in that gospel as well, you have Lazarus writing the story from the third person.

Luke is the Gospel I know the least about, tbh. I'd be interested in knowing how it was revised against Marcion. Not that I really doubt it, but our manuscripts mostly date after him, so I'm not sure how you could be certain.

parent.body:
In this case, I think the "whole world" means the "whole world".

* If God was grieved to the point of wanting to wipe "all flesh" from the face of the earth, what's the point in a local flood?
* Were people in other regions just suddenly irrelevant?
* Why did Noah need to build an ark to save all the animals just in that one region?
* Why couldn't Noah and his family (and any animals that needed saving) just walk to a different region?
* Why are birds included in the ark — couldn't they just fly somewhere else?
* How were the _mountains_ covered "to a depth of more than fifteen cubits" if it was just a local flood?
* How could a local-only flood experience constant heavy downpour rain for 40 days, rising waters for 150 days, and over a year of time before it was dry and safe enough to exit the ark?

Whether or not you believe in a global flood, I don't think the Bible leaves any room for interpretation on its intended meaning of a _global_ flood.
parent.body_html:
In this case, I think the "whole world" means the "whole world".

  • If God was grieved to the point of wanting to wipe "all flesh" from the face of the earth, what's the point in a local flood?
  • Were people in other regions just suddenly irrelevant?
  • Why did Noah need to build an ark to save all the animals just in that one region?
  • Why couldn't Noah and his family (and any animals that needed saving) just walk to a different region?
  • Why are birds included in the ark — couldn't they just fly somewhere else?
  • How were the mountains covered "to a depth of more than fifteen cubits" if it was just a local flood?
  • How could a local-only flood experience constant heavy downpour rain for 40 days, rising waters for 150 days, and over a year of time before it was dry and safe enough to exit the ark?

Whether or not you believe in a global flood, I don't think the Bible leaves any room for interpretation on its intended meaning of a global flood.

post.body:
Noah and company also descended from Adam and Eve.

So the races must have "evolved" from Noah's time until today, didn't they?

A literal reading of the story of the Flood was that the whole world was destroyed except for Noah and a few others, so then the different races that we see today must have genetically come from this lineage.

Does anyone have any more understanding or info on this topic?

UPDATE: [Deluge Catholic Encyclopedia article](https://www.newadvent.org/cathen/04702a.htm) admits some other possibilities, for example: 

> Besides, the oldest Egyptian monuments present the Negro race just as we find it today, so that even at that remote age, it was wholly different from the Caucasian race.

> Considerations like these have induced several Catholic writers to regard as quite tenable the opinion that the Deluge did not destroy all men outside the ark.

This just moves the question back to how the races descended from Adam and Eve though

body: Several of them, not just Irenaeus. I doubt their claims but it's unlikely that they fabricated Marcion's actual text, especially in such a way that it removes almost exclusively material unique to Luke, *and* just so happens to be what looks to have been added later. Changing what people knew Marcion's gospel said would've been too obvious anyway, as they were already onto the church about altering the text.

Oh, probably Irenaeus. I thought you meant the real thing.

I'm always skeptical of the Church Fathers when it comes to the Gnostics, because from what we have of them, it looks like the good ol' boys might have engaged in quite a bit of fibbing. Or at best, spreading rumors.
